p: Reduction in foliar phenolics at elevated temperatures ( Julkunen-Tiitto et al., 2015) has been explained by a dilution effect whereby more carbon was allocated to growth supporting structures with turnover of phenolics slow or even absent ( Kosonen et al., 2012). Recently, it has been reported that warming reduces flavonoids ( Nissinen et al., 2016; Zhang et al., 2018), salicylates and phenolic acids ( Sivadasan et al., 2018) in deciduous trees and total phenolics in a conifer ( Zhang et al., 2018). Flavonoids, alkaloids, and saponins (triterpenes) were increased in Robinia pseudoacacia grown in warmer open-top chambers compared to seedlings grown in an open field ( Zhao et al., 2016). However, enclosure may significantly affect foliar PSCs ( Peltonen et al., 2005).
